subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Way/Why
msgSnippet: John, That sounds like a reasonable hypothesis to me.  Proper spelling is engrained in most people today, but I believe that in Elizabethan times the concept
messageBody:
John,

That sounds like a reasonable hypothesis to me.  Proper spelling is engrained in most people today, but I believe that in Elizabethan times the concept of a "correct" spelling was either non-existent or much weaker.  I would argue that if it is clear what word you are intending to represent, a slightly different spelling from an arbitrary "standard" should cause no difficulty in reading.

I think it is fair to say that most languages are not spread around the globe as widely as English is so alternate pronunciations in English may be more likely to occur.  Another point is that English seems peculiarly resistant to modification of standardized spelling over time when pronunciation has changed as compared to other languages such as German or Spanish.  Perhaps that is due to the independent nature of the English Speaking Peoples.

I have not gone back and checked the group messages from the past, but I remember long detailed discussions about how necessary standardizing QS spelling was.  The people pushing this idea seem much more focused on this than seems necessary to me, and they seemed very adamant about it.  I see it as a slippery slope.  Okay, now that we have straightened out English spelling and made it sensible again, let's start back down the same path that got us into this mess to begin with.

Regards,


Paige Gabhart

P.S.  The state of English spelling brings about other unanticipated results.  Recently, I have noticed people spelling the names of their children in ways that do not follow normal English spelling precepts.  These parents appear to believe that letters may be freely put into words and then ignored in the pronunciation of the resulting name.  I guess the letter is stuck in to provide "uniqueness."  Example:  "Elijiah," but pronounced according to the parent as "Elijah;" or "Tanikia" pronounced "Tanika."  I suspect if you asked them what the extra, unpronounced "i" was for, they would look at you blankly.  This may go back to the number of exceptions that actual English spelling presents when compared to the standard spelling rules.  I think many people do not understand the concept that each letter should represent a sound present in the word. 

The idea of the existence of "silent" letters brings this out.  A couple of years ago I learned of an elementary teacher who was telling her young students that the "h" in words such as "which" and "why" was a silent letter.  Presumably, for her it was, but I suspect she had no idea that many people still pronounce it and consider it important.  No wonder it is a dying sound with that lack of knowledge on the part of the people teaching our children.


On 2/21/2013 12:25 PM, John Cowan wrote:
 

Paige Gabhart scripsit:

> I agree as well. Unstandardized QS does not affect
> understandability. So if that is the case then it should not be a
> problem for people to write as they speak. I am a U.S. citizen, and
> in the mid 70s I corresponded with a man in New Zealand in QS. I
> had no difficulty in understanding his QS. I think the drive toward
> standardizing QS arises out of the same human desire for uniformity
> that sent TO down the wrong path centuries ago.

Historically, the pressure to standardize orthographies comes from publishers,
who need to know the difference between a typo they should correct and a mere
variant spelling they must preserve. By not having variant spellings, the
distinction is more obvious. I know of no orthography generally used for
published works that is not standardized.

--
John Cowan http://ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...

The Linux-nationale / Shall Microsoft outpace,
We can write better programs / Our CPUs won't stall,
So raise the penguin banner of / The Linux-nationale. --Greg Baker
